VowHByyLqYs.title: What does Microsoft want with Linux and Open Source?

snippet.textDisplay: This is simply speculation
snippet.textOriginal: This is simply speculation

snippet.textDisplay:
I don't think Microsoft is trying to hurt Linux, I think they're trying to make Windows better.
And IMO they've succeeded massively, I love WSL and use it daily. You can even run KVM inside WSL if you need to, and the performance overhead seems close to zero (which I suppose makes sense, as WSL runs in a kernel level hypervisor alongside Windows, rather than inside Windows).
And, it all solves the biggest issues I've had with Linux over my life (accidentally sudo'ing something, or just apt-getting something, and having my desktop environment just cease working, or have grub stop working, etc), because if you get it to an unsavable state, you just right click the app, and reset it, and within 5 minutes everything just works again. If I have package manager dependency conflicts, worst case I can just use a second WSL installation. It's so good.
And it means tensorflow, which used to be notoriously painful to get working on Windows is now pretty easy to use with WSL, and integrated support for WSL in VSCode, etc mean developing stuff for Linux command line is pretty easy too. And all this is not to mention WSA allowing you to have the same seamless experience with Android apps.
It is uh, rough that it's taken away any desire I really had to dual boot though.
snippet.textOriginal:
I don't think Microsoft is trying to hurt Linux, I think they're trying to make Windows better.
And IMO they've succeeded massively, I love WSL and use it daily. You can even run KVM inside WSL if you need to, and the performance overhead seems close to zero (which I suppose makes sense, as WSL runs in a kernel level hypervisor alongside Windows, rather than inside Windows).
And, it all solves the biggest issues I've had with Linux over my life (accidentally sudo'ing something, or just apt-getting something, and having my desktop environment just cease working, or have grub stop working, etc), because if you get it to an unsavable state, you just right click the app, and reset it, and within 5 minutes everything just works again. If I have package manager dependency conflicts, worst case I can just use a second WSL installation. It's so good.
And it means tensorflow, which used to be notoriously painful to get working on Windows is now pretty easy to use with WSL, and integrated support for WSL in VSCode, etc mean developing stuff for Linux command line is pretty easy too. And all this is not to mention WSA allowing you to have the same seamless experience with Android apps.
It is uh, rough that it's taken away any desire I really had to dual boot though.

snippet.textDisplay:
In the past, I had a dual boot with Ubuntu for programming. Now, I never launch real Linux anymore, the Windows default Linux is enough for what I'm looking for (the packet manager way of installing dev libraries) while using a Windows IDE.

What I dislike about Linux are the mediocre default graphical user interfaces. It's fun if you want to spend hours making your personal UI, but if you just want to use the Linux dev ecosystem, I don't want Ubuntu's overhead.

Linux will suffer due to Microsft. I think only dev tools and libraries will survive, nobody will be making Linux software with a GUI anymore. Firefox for Linux will die, people will just write bots using Linux browser engines, not actually browse the web on Linux.

snippet.textDisplay:
Are there really open source die-hards saying Linux doesn't need the benefit of having Microsoft services? "We don't need them, we don't want them." Probably the stupidest thing I've heard. I thought these people wanted Linux to dominate. What happened to the years and years of saying "this will be the year of Linux, no really." Like this guy said, people are reluctant to change. I've tried several times to get others to consider a Linux OS so they could worry less about safety, but they rejected it full stop when I told them they wouldn't be able to use Microsoft Word.

At this rate, Linux is doomed to forever lose desktop marketshare. 99% of computer users don't give a shit about package managers, bash scripting, or command lines. They especially don't give a shit about Microsoft Office alternatives when Microsoft Office exists.

snippet.textDisplay:
I don't think microsoft is using its EEE strategy with WSL. This is because there are so many other programs that exist today which you could use and still get 90-95% similar experience as wsl.

1. You could use linux on the cloud through digitalocean or linode. You could have windows on your host system, install putty (a software not created and mantained by microsoft) and ssh into your digitalocean droplet or linode and you can get the same experience. You could also install gnome and xfce and do remote desktop and use GUI features.

2. You could use something like virtualbox or vmware workstation (softwares not mantained or created by microsoft) and install ubuntu and get the same experience as wsl.

3. If you need only linux cli, you could use docker or vagrant and install any linux cli tool you want.

And speaking of opensource, Apple only has one major opensource project, Swift, which is also available on linux and windows. At least microsoft has created many more opensource projects and made them available on other platforms.

You could also install gnome and xfce and do remote desktop and use GUI features.

2. You could use something like virtualbox or vmware workstation (softwares not mantained or created by microsoft) and install ubuntu and get the same experience as wsl.

3. If you need only linux cli, you could use docker or vagrant and install any linux cli tool you want.

And speaking of opensource, Apple only has one major opensource project, Swift, which is also available on linux and windows. At least microsoft has created many more opensource projects and made them available on other platforms.

snippet.textDisplay: What is truly funky is that early operating systems were Open source.   When you paid IBM for that OS360 license,you got the source and built it for your system.      Later,companies closed their source,  making it a sealed sacred product of the type well known in the Windows world.      Windows 95 would crash when an integer in the date and time system rolled over.   This happen every 29 plus days.   The PUEL says you may have one other computer accessing a machine running extended Virtualbox    The attached computer must be used to view Virtualbox output.   It implicitly denies the Virtualbox host from serving connections to other machines while Virtualbox is running.     The PUEL would forbid many common uses of  Virtualbox, including its use by many Youtubers.   No wonder many alternative VM systems are being built for the Linux world.   I have not used an unenhanced Virtualbox.   I may  install a basic system on a a spare drive,just to test raw Virtualbox and other VM support systems.  I am a home user, so I do not have the limitations of a commercial user.

snippet.textDisplay: the only thing keeping me from using linux 100% of the time is instrumental plugins like spitfire (even though I can run them on wine staging 7.2 with no major problems). But there are amazing instruments available like pianoteq so I think things will just keep improving. Regarding open source software, we have ardour and really great synths but I really hope we get to see more orchestral stuff. I think technologies like physical modeling (which pianoteq uses) have great potential for that because it's just sound made by software, no large and expensive ensembles. I'm an engineer and I'm really willing to contribute to something like this.

snippet.textDisplay: Hi, it is nice to see the enthusiasm you have about what you do. I have been using Linux Mint 19.3 for about 10 months and I think it is great!  First I had/have a Windows 10 Dell laptop with an i7 processor that sometimes got real slow. I became very annoyed with Windows 10. Then I bought a HP Chromebook. It is real fast at booting up and surfing the web but did not have much in the way of software available. Then I tried Linux Mint by installing it on an old Dell laptop that was given to me. This started my use of Linux  and it became my favorite OS. I am 71 years old and my first computer had Microsoft DOS 5.0 and booted to DOS Shell. I have just this week installed Linux Mint 20 as a dual boot on my Dell laptop with an i7 processor and a 1 TB hard drive. I am excited about having Linux Mint on my main computer and don't think I will use Windows 10 much.

Us benefiting is just a side bonus.

snippet.textDisplay:
Descendants of penguins

In fact, all these years we have been wrong. And the truth is this:
Once upon a time, the ancient race of the Supreme Penguins flew to our planet, left their colonists here and flew away. Colonists settled on the planet and created dinosaurs with their genial technologies. But then one of the Supreme Penguin ships crashed into the planet, and after that the temperature on Earth rose. Some of the colonists took refuge at the South Pole, then the High Penguins who flew away returned and cooled the planet with a special substance called Frostonium. Then the colonists again settled all over the planet, but the technologies were hidden in the ice of Antarctica. Over the course of hundreds of thousands of years, the High Penguins began to metamorphose, and after the metamorphosis they began to evolve. So, from the Highest Penguins the Penguinopithecs originated, and from them all the ancient animals, and evolution proceeded along the already known way. This is how we humans happened, and as a tribute to our ancestors, we created Linux, the best operating system.
Owlet "Sowich" flyer, 12.27.2021

snippet.textDisplay:
this is from 2017, and i'm writing may 2022, BUT, Minetest did exist back when this was made. I believe Minestest started life in 2012 or so, but anyway, if you're looking for a Minecraft clone, there are 2 good MC clone games, one is called Mineclonia, and the other is called Mineclone 2.

now, leaving Minecraft behind, the real strength of Minetest is all the mods available to create your own unique game, building on top of the very (deliberately) basic voxel sandbox worlds of 'Minetest Game', or, download other games from the built in content database, or better yet, explore and join the communities of hosted online multiplayer games, some of which are MC clones, but mostly are unique games unto themselves, and quite a few servers include mods unique to the server. Very cool, and lots to see and do and participate.

learn coding, make some mods, or modify existing mods in the easy to learn Lua language. there are great tutorials for modding for Minestest.

Minetest is better than Minecraft, IMHO.

G603BdiDlZc.title: The Future Of Open Source Linux Documentation?

snippet.textDisplay:
I recognize that this is part of Devuan's crusade against systemd and if it weren't systemd-related we probably wouldn't have had any attempt to conflate this knowledgebase article with "systemd documentation". It fits his narrative so he's spinning it more wildly than a major party political candidate for national office.

That said, I think this is bad behavior on Red Hat/IBM's part. A paywall is a paywall is a paywall. Gentoo, Debian, Arch, Ubuntu, Mint, Pop! … no other Linux distribution I know of conceals its user documentation behind any kind of paywall. And I don't know how many times I have learned something useful from the Arch wiki despite the fact that I've used Arch Linux a total of three weeks in my life some almost ten years ago no, wow. It's just the most complete set of Linux user-focused documentation available anywhere.

I'm into vintage computers—as in Apple II in this case. There's one seller of Apple II products on eBay … he's known for selling at about the highest REASONABLE prices you could expect to pay. And he's got a website full of documentation. Curated, admittedly, but fundamentally all written by someone else. He locks it behind access credentials he'll give to anyone who has bought from him. It's documentation of general interest to anyone who cares about the Apple II, it is available on other site(s) unless or until the owners of those sites are lost to attrition (let's face it, Apple II users are at least in their 40s, if not significantly older), and we do lose one or two people now and then who knew everything there was to know about these machines. And some large portion of what they knew dies with them.

For all I know, this guy might well have the last copy of some documentation stored previously on a domain owned by the late Tony Diaz. The only way I'm likely to find out is to pay probably $425 for a machine worth $300-400 that he bought for a song at an estate sale and then ask him for access to the site. Or figure out if Google has a cache I can read. Or something like that. His pages sure shows up in search results, though! I personally consider the guy to be a parasite to the community. He contributes nothing, but he's all too happy to take what others have created for himself.

Is what Red Hat/IBM is doing all that different? Well obviously they write systemd and other components, so they are contributing _something_. Within the past week or so I had a fun time trying to get dracut to work and ran into frustrations because the documentation I would need to explain how to do what I was trying to accomplish didn't exist in the wild—or at least its buried under years-outdated forums and blog posts that don't work or at least don't work anymore. Is the answer on the Red Hat knowledgebase website? Don't know. But even if it is, the "individual developer" program is relatively new, and it might disappear in the future.

And sure, probably all of the documentation for RHEL is described somewhere, somehow, probably in a different way, on some other website. But they've locked this version of it (and lots of other documentation) behind a paywall. Is that okay? It's not the end of the world, certainly, but it's bad behavior all the same.

snippet.textDisplay: software patents should be outlawed. Nearly all software patents are for algorithms that are obvious and which are used by everyone who solves the same problem independently. There's very little that's unique or not obvious in software patents. France and the EU have the right approach. Often software patents are used as a bargaining chip between large corps which have huge portfolios of software patents. Software patents are like domain names: hundreds of people can have the same idea at the same time, but only one gets to register the domain name. At the very least, these troll companies should have to implement their ideas in code. But personally I'd throw them all out, unless they are truly ground-breaking and need protection.

snippet.textDisplay: Hi!! There is a new Linux native GTK open-source note-taking app called TECHNENOTES (which I am actively developing). Although there are multiple amazing note-taking app out there, I do think that TechneNotes has some strong points, starting from the database-like interface (with pagination, ordering, filtering, all combined with a treeview structure), the safety of local data storage with optional cloud sync (users choose if and how to sync data over the cloud), multi-tabs support with full-width note view, integration of text/files/images/videos as in a web-page, interconnected notes, standard markdown syntax (for cross-compatibility), and - most of all - its native (Gtk) and open source nature (thus ensuring that your notes will be fully accessible in the future, with no risk of vendor lock-in)

snippet.textDisplay: Extremely BETA open-sourced drivers, but I do have hopes for the future that everything will operate the same under Linux as it always has with it's closed-source proprietary counterpart drivers have. Vulkan and OpenGL should still work the same for rendering without having too much trouble, possibly better performance will be gained since the Linux kernel can be tuned to fit the specifications of the GPUs design and architecture, also hoping for a better Nvidia Settings panel which still looks like something built in the 1990s. Better GPU support under Xorg and Wayland, since Wayland is considered better for multi-monitor setups, but no network transport for external displays, which falls back to X11 backend, Xorg is pretty dated at this point and it's not necessarily being updated to be more modern with today's software standards.

snippet.textDisplay: I am 99.99999% sure this was done for their machine learning/datacenter customers that often need additional flexibility. Having an open source driver for these kinds of applications can more quickly let customers that encounter serious bugs fix it themselves without having to go through the process of reporting the bug to Nvidia and then waiting a few months for it to be rolled into a driver update. The fact that there's still closed-source blobs that are required, though, big red flag from Nvidia. My guess is that some of the code in the blob can't be easily shared without compromising something, maybe it's core features they can't share due to licensing/security restrictions? I doubt we'll ever see the official Nvidia drivers in mainline, though.

snippet.textDisplay: Linux (Ubuntu) is my primary desktop and also my AD domain controller (CENTOS).  I've been using it for years and I can tell you, despite all the logistic advantages of Linux, it will never truly compete with Windows on the desktop for a very simple reason:  the majority of people are appliance operators and have no desire to learn a CL.  They want to turn it on and do what they want to do. Until Linux becomes as "user dumb" as Windows, it will continue to be the OS of choice for advanced users, developers, and engineers.  And, the continuing prevalence of *nix snobs in community forums is a serious issue.  The ones that like to tell people that they shouldn't be using a *nux GUI and must learn to use the command line.  That attitude holds Linux back from becoming mainstream.

snippet.textDisplay:
A few more things:
Linux links and short cut keys work from anywhere on the system, but Windows links with short cuts have to be on the desktop.
Short cut keys the user creates in Linux are not tied to links.
I can also change my keyboard keys on the fly with bash scripts and short cut keys.
Power Shell is a pain to use compared to Bash. You mentioned that, but it is a real pain by not being intuitive in it's commands. They should have built on CMD.
It's easier to access your encrypted drive with Linux. With Windows you might end up without being able to access the drive.
File sharing is easier with Linux, and can be secured better. You can even make hidden shares, and restrict the types of files sent.
Linux can stay running 24/7. Windows often messes up an application meant to run 24/7, like security cameras, with as little as checking for updates.
Programing my G604 mouse is more reliable and easier in Linux than Windows.
More wear and tear on the OS drive in Windows than Linux.
Auto downloading of Windows updates can drag everything to a crawl in Windows. Not so with Linux, which is why my spouse switched to Linux.

snippet.textDisplay: The stupid thing about the Command Prompt / Terminal with Windows is, the command-line interface used to be so important to Microsoft. To the point that the original DOS (which was already showing massive promise with various versions - my first encounter was Acorn Computers version called Acorn-MOS - and was getting pretty advanced in what you could do with it, even ending with the very first early signs of an actual graphical DE) was completely murdered by them through completely evil and dirty, sometimes borderline illegal (or outright illegal) practises, until everyone finally gave in and let their own, crappy, less-advanced version "MS-DOS" take over entirely. And then they went and dumped it anyway ... and now they're trying to bring it back again after realising their mistake.

snippet.textDisplay: Not quite correct about AMD. AMD had a proprietary OpenCL driver called Orca, for Polaris GPUs and earlier. All later GPUs use rocm-opencl, which is under the MIT license. The "problem" is that it's part of the ROCm stack, not Mesa, and most distros don't ship ROCm because it's huge, complex, hard to maintain and the documentation is lacking. Arch wants it in core for example, but won't include it as long as it requires its own forked LLVM infrastructure. It's on the AUR though, and works perfectly fine. Should be available on most distros these days, either through third party repos or directly from AMD.
snippet.textOriginal: Not quite correct about AMD. AMD had a proprietary OpenCL driver called Orca, for Polaris GPUs and earlier. All later GPUs use rocm-opencl, which is under the MIT license. The "problem" is that it's part of the ROCm stack, not Mesa, and most distros don't ship ROCm because it's huge, complex, hard to maintain and the documentation is lacking. Arch wants it in core for example, but won't include it as long as it requires its own forked LLVM infrastructure. It's on the AUR though, and works perfectly fine. Should be available on most distros these days, either through third party repos or directly from AMD.

snippet.textDisplay:
I think the problem with Linux is hardcore Linux users have a Superiority complex. If you couldn't make the High School football team and you suddenly found Linux, because you can tinker with an OS, you see yourself as a computer engineer which is not a good approach. One other issue not everyone is a computer expert and that's where the Superiority complex for hardcore Linux users step in. An average consumer wants something that works and what I found since Linux is underground (even in 2022), hardcore Linux users criticize people who don't want to learn programing and tinkering with a system. I don't think a street food vendor in East Los Angeles is going to join the hardcore Linux user realm because they're a street food vendor which Linux doesn't serve a purpose in their day to day life. The wrong people promote Linux. I hear of a lot of exaggerated claims of Linux and a lot of the flaws are ignored. I myself tinkered with Linux distros and had several break on me and had updates and repositories mess up my system. A very small group of Hardcore Linux users thinks Arch Linux is the standard of a computer OS which it was one of the most difficult OS I ever ran. The Hardcore Linux user will counter back that Windows is no different when you get a virus, blue screen, hacked, have to reinstall because of spam, cookies, etc. Hardcore users use talking points to mock non Linux users because their lack of knowledge of advance computer tinkering.

I don't expect a street food vendor from Los Angeles to know how to operate the PACMAN repository system in Arch Linux because average person isn't deep in that Linux realm. People aren't complacent (Windows and Mac users), they're just not Linux users and use Linux as a hobby.

snippet.textDisplay:
I use arch as a daily driver, on an nvidia gpu computer (sorry XD). and honestly it isn't as unstable as people think it is. I haven't been using it for long. But if you want to learn, there are some details that you can only learn when using it as daily driver. I'm not a fan of arch, nor it's philosophy, I just like the experience and the learning process. the system is unstable when you do something wrong, and when you're trying to fix it, you learn what you did wrong and how things work the right way.
Maybe you can't use it if you want something working out of the box and you want things done quickly and efficiently. But IMHO arch is good as a daily driver, it even serves more the purpose of learning if used that way. and you end up with things that works exactly how you wanted it to work, which is a nice feature to have (I for example am a huge fan of minimalism. I don't ever want to install anything that I don't absolutely need. and things are working great for me., I feel like this can be done better with gentoo for example , which is on my to-try list, But so far, the best pleasent minimalist system install I had is my current one)

snippet.textDisplay:
I have used Linux for 3 years now I still dual boot windows for games since Linux is very much lacking in that aspect but anything productivity related goes to Linux. I have only 3 issues with the Linux community and open source community as a whole.
1. the borderline religious dogma of the open source community(obviously not all I can't believe I have to type this since it should be inferred): when I talk to Windows users they see it as a tool. when I talk to other Linux users they see it as they are on a crusade against Microsoft and Apple and talk about how using open source software is the moral thing rather than talking about it's Pros and Cons as a tool.
2. the Linux and open source community tends to be privacy focused (which is a good thing) but they take it to the Nth degree. saying you should sacrifice all convenience in the name of privacy, saying that all online services are useless and you should be hosting your own VPN, Cloud storage, not using a Password manager, etc.. if you want modern conveniences you do have to sacrifice a little of privacy, want free entertainment while financially supporting the content providers you have to watch ads.
3. the idea that all proprietary software is bad and inferior to open source software when in some case its the exact opposite. proof in case photoshop vs gimp as good as gimp has gotten it still lags very much behind photoshop in feature set, OpenGL, Vulkan vs DirectX OpenGL has always lagged behind DirectX as a Gaming API and while Vulkan has closed the gap in terms of performance but it still lacks many features that DirectX offers like direct storage, hardware decompression.
I love Linux and opensource software but I want to recognize it faults so it gets better, at the end of the day Linux and OSS is a tool used to gets tasks done.

snippet.textDisplay: I think that the toxic part of the Linux community (which is way less than it was 10-15 years ago) actually don't want new users. They're perfectly happy with what they consider to be an elite group to stay small. As far as the choices....I like to use the example of someone who's been locked up for the majority of their adult life and suddenly they find themselves free. The amount of freedoms and choices you have with Linux is daunting and paralyzing to someone completely new to Linux. However, those same freedoms and choices are what makes Linux better in a lot of ways. If you don't like the way Windows does something, then you don't have much choice about it. If you don't like something on a particular Linux distro, you can either change it or go with a different Linux distro. You're not tied down. You don't have a big cooperation trying to act like they know what you need, even if you don't actually need or want it.

snippet.textDisplay:
I use my computer for gaming. Linux doesn't properly cater to that. It's also an end-user headache. I don't know Linux and don't want to learn it. I must admit I found this video by searching "linux elitism". So I am here to validate my own opinion, yes.

Thanks for the video, though.

I have met people claiming Linux is superior. If I say "well, I need to be a programmer to achieve the same result as Windows" I am skeptical that anyone can justify making the change to me. I know Windows and it works. Maybe Linux "works better" but why switch to a non-native OS that I don't have years of experience navigating? It just seems like a waste of time for anyone who isn't in love with code. I like things that are practical, if it's not broke, don't fix it.

I appreciate the endeavor, it just seems completely useless for me as a product/tool.

snippet.textDisplay:
As someone who uses Arch (btw) here’s my personal answer to that last one:
- I love the AUR. I don’t like dealing with snaps, flatpaks or appimages (but my reasons for that are a whole other discussion) and, thanks to the AUR, I don’t have to. Also, on Ubuntu, some of the packages I wanted just weren’t available (not even as snaps) so I had to compile directly from source and manually manage updates and dependencies. Not really a deal-breaker but it kinda defeats the purpose of having a package manager.
- The wiki is amazing! I’ve never had an easier time finding info about anything I wanted to customise or was struggling with.
- I like the rolling release model.
- I like the idea of having a more lightweight system I build myself. From my experience, it runs faster and it’s easier to understand. On Ubuntu, I basically had to treat everything like a black box and, when the box didn’t work, I had a harder time fixing it.
- It started out as a fun challenge and tinkering with it continues to be fun (I’m a CS student and I’ve learnt more about Linux in a few weeks running Arch than in the entire first year of my degree running Ubuntu).

snippet.textDisplay: Here is the fix to Ubuntu crashing apps or screen freeze.  Disable swap:  run swapoff <del>a and sudo sed -i '/ swap / s/^\(.*\)$/#\1/g' /etc/fstab.  Also comment out the reference to swap in /etc/fstab. Start by editing the following file</del>  sudo nano /etc/fstab.  Reboot your computer.   No more screen freeze or apps crashing and also notice a performance boost with Ubuntu.

snippet.textDisplay:
JStock isn't fully open source - the github repo has no license and says the code doesn't even compile without proprietary components.

It also looks like it's made by one guy in Malaysia, so it's a bit suspicious.

If you're interested in learning some basic double-entry accounting, you can use apps like GnuCash to track stocks.

There are also open source CLI accounting apps, with optional web/mobile interfaces, like ledger (C++), beancount (Python), and hledger (Haskell). Here's some more info about those: https://plaintextaccounting.org/

Webull is a brokerage with a great app that has a great interface (mobile/web) and tons of features (including crypto trading) - you can use my link to get a few free stocks - https://act.webull.com/pm/m3K5KA8iL5m6/3cm/inviteUs/. You can also track stocks that aren't in Webull using Watchlists and Simulated Holdings (so you could even split up retirement vs non-retirement accounts that way and track them separately).

Then there's also Google Sheets and creating a custom spreadsheet for stock tracking from it - that works well on desktop and decently on mobile. One of the advantages of this is using the "GOOGLEFINANCE" function to automatically look up stock prices, dividends, and other info and updating your numbers based on that. Some financial youtubers, like MeetKevin and Andrei Jikh, release their own custom investment tracking spreadsheets you can download and use.

There are also open source CLI accounting apps, with optional web/mobile interfaces, like ledger (C++), beancount (Python), and hledger (Haskell). Here's some more info about those: https://plaintextaccounting.org/

Webull is a brokerage with a great app that has a great interface (mobile/web) and tons of features (including crypto trading) - you can use my link to get a few free stocks - https://act.webull.com/pm/m3K5KA8iL5m6/3cm/inviteUs/. You can also track stocks that aren't in Webull using Watchlists and Simulated Holdings (so you could even split up retirement vs non-retirement accounts that way and track them separately).

Then there's also Google Sheets and creating a custom spreadsheet for stock tracking from it - that works well on desktop and decently on mobile. One of the advantages of this is using the "GOOGLEFINANCE" function to automatically look up stock prices, dividends, and other info and updating your numbers based on that. Some financial youtubers, like MeetKevin and Andrei Jikh, release their own custom investment tracking spreadsheets you can download and use.

snippet.textDisplay:
HOW THE F*CK DO YOU RUN THIS CHANNEL WITHOUT UNDERSTANDING WHAT OPEN-SOURCE MEANS?!


Open source doesn't mean free of charge, that would otherwise include all Google and Facebook products or shitty little mobile games. It also doesn't mean "can run on Linux".
Open source means that the source code before compilation can be accessed publicly.
In most cases people are allowed to alter the code and submit improvements and changes.
Note that this does not apply to black-magic design products or lightworks at all.
the free version of Fusion is merely an incentive to buy other black-magic products or the full version of Fusion. If it were open-source, you could just go ahead and remove the restrictions that the free version has, or just download the full version in the first place.

snippet.textDisplay: You didn't mention the most important component of successful  open source software: the GPL license. That is what keeps any company from copyrighting your software and then demanding payment from you to let you use your own software. If you invest your time on software that a company can take back at any time, you effectively are working for that company for free,  and you will not be even allowed to use the software you wrote later. Open source software is a great resource to learn programming and coding, but without a GPL license most projects don't get that far. Sure, there is BSD and X11, paid for the US government in the form of college grants, but GNU and Linux got to be the stupendous projects they are because they use the GPL license. Without GPL, you are strictly working for somebody else for free, you don't get money and you don't get the end product either.

snippet.textDisplay: Since I switched to linux in 2010, I tried a few mail clients, like Thunderbird, Slypheed, Geary and windows mail. Now that I'm back from windows 10 to ubuntu, I'm trying Springmail. Thunderbird was not bad after I set up a flat theme, but the layout is a bit too outdated now. Sylpheed gets the job done, but I think at that point I could as well go to mutt. Geary was rather nice under gnome 3, but I had many stability issues, until I dropped it completely. When I was in W10, the default mail client was my choice, and it was working well, being clean and going straight to the point. And when I went back to ubuntu, since W10 is slowly going toward its end of support, I wanted something similar but more stable than Geary. And that's where I try Springmail. So far, not too bad. Sure, it looks like an apple app, and I can't easily make a folder as read, but it seems to be quite close to the windows mail.

snippet.textDisplay:
Ni Nick, something I've had problems with for years, no matter the OS I'm running. But every third party e-mail client I get has a tendency to mess with iCloud's default folder behavior. They'll create their own folders on the IMAP server. They mess up everything, putting things in local folders, putting messages in unique folders, etc. I'm an iPhone user that uses Linux, Windows, and MacOS. But my main personal e-mail is an iCloud address. I also, like most people, have a GMail address as well. So, if it plays nicely with Gmail too, all the better.

Which e-mail client do you recommend that will not screw with the default iCloud IMAP folder behavior? Bonus points if it has a unified Inbox!

snippet.textDisplay: Lavoro nell’IT come sistemista da 18 anni in ambito misto Linux e Windows ma molto di più su Microsoft. Ho dedicato del mio tempo libero per conseguire la LPIC-1 che ho preso due giorni fa. Detto questo, anche se mi assumessero domani, non sarei subito “pronto e scattante”, perché su Linux non ci lavoro da anni e non ci ho mai lavorato tanto a fondo. Intendo dire che sicuramente la certificazione è un plus, ma conta molto di più cosa sai fare nella pratica.

snippet.textDisplay: Ho fatto una prima esperienza in un azienda che usava solo prodotti open source vedi debian, linguaggio ruby piuttosto che python e configurazione firewall, server, backup sempre con questi . Abbiamo realizzato anche progetti complessi ma purtroppo devo dire che nel mondo reale del lavoro sistemistico non ne vale assolutamente la pena a bassi livelli.....Ossia devi avere competenze elevate, logicamente configurando tutto nel dettaglio vi sono molte ma molte possibilità di errore, vi sono delle limitazioni vedi samba e infine il cliente paga poco e rompe un casino le palle..Risultato lavori per non troppi soldi, ad elevate competenze e per una manutenzione impegnativa. Microsoft ormai con la nuova infrastruttura e solido, una volta impostato il tutto vi e backup , ridondanze, load balancer automatici ecc....Tutte cose che fare da 0 o in parte con linux richiederebbero un super lavorone. Nel ecosistema microsoft servono cmq molte conoscenze ma la manutenzione viene fatta da sola ed e super efficente......Risultato con microsoft metti in piedi il progetto, i problemi saranno molto pochi e in caso di rotture di palle sara colpa di micorosft il cliente non potra romepre i coglioni e si lamenta con un colosso non lo cagano...Insomma nel mondo piccolo linux , livello sistemistico non fai i soldi con linux....Togliendo manutenzione e installazioni semplificiate, ormai l integrazione office 365 presente nelle aziende elimina ancora di piu l infrastruttura linux che al massimo viene usato per backup o app web

snippet.textDisplay: Ho iniziato a usare Linux a 16 anni, nel 1996 quando provai una vecchissima Red Hat da un CD recuperato da una rivista, pensate che c'era ancora il kernel 1.x e KDE 1.x. All'epoca Linux era considerato una cosa per molto più che smanettoni, era una roba che non conosceva quasi nessuno, tranne i più nerd dei nerd. Ma avevo intuito che mi sarebbe servito "da grande" e così non smisi mai di usarlo e di formarmi, dato che all'epoca non esisteva nemmeno col binocolo una certificazione Linux. Intuizione azzeccata! Ormai sono quasi 30 anni che lo uso quindi e non c'è stata cosa che mi è stata più utile nel mio lavoro di sviluppatore quanto una conoscenza approfondita di Linux, tra l'altro l'ho usato come sistema operativo a lavoro dal 2004 al 2012, anno in cui ho cambiato lavoro e sono stato costretto a usare Windows, ma a casa ovviamente non ho cambiato la mia preferenza. Sono contento che ci siano delle certificazioni e credetemi, non è assolutamente vero che la conoscenza di Linux non è apprezzata, per me è stata determinante già nel 2004, figuriamoci oggi... Tranne ovviamente che non lavoriate in Visual Basic...

snippet.textDisplay:
Sei bravo, chiaro e fai analisi quasi sempre corrette, complimenti.
Un unico appunto, tenendo presente che sono un "vecchietto" di sessant'anni che potrebbe essere tuo nonno: è proprio necessario usare sempre e solo terminologia inglese? Di tutte le specializzazioni che hai citato si poteva fare la traduzione in italiana, altrettanto chiara ed esaustiva.
Non che mi piacciano, anzi... ma sono certo che i francesi si sarebbero ben guardati da usare parole straniere anche in questo campo, tenendo presente che per loro il PC è l'ordinateur, il mouse si chiama rat... e così via.
Continua così che vai forte, in bocca al lupo!!

“Upscale images like in any police investigation show.”

US Marshals, where a CCTV image is magnified to show fingerprint impressions made on the outside of gloves from the wearer’s hand, sitting in a garbage can in the dark: “You dare challenge me?”
